subject: Event Announcement: YS Think Intercultural Series: Unlocking Cultural Intelligence: A Practical Framework by Dr Catherine Peyrols Wu, 01 Apr 2025
body:
Dear Vincent Bongiovanni,
You are invited to the following 
event
:
YS Think Intercultural Series: Unlocking Cultural Intelligence: A Practical Framework by Dr Catherine Peyrols Wu
When: 01 Apr 2025 12:00 PM, CEST
Where: Online
The event is in 5 days, have you registered?
Yes
 
Maybe
 
No
 
EVENT DETAILS:
Expand Your Intercultural Skills with this interactive session!
Part 1
 – Essential Insights (20 min)
What is Cultural Intelligence (CQ), and how can you apply its powerful framework to elevate your intercultural training? Discover key concepts and real-world applications.
Part 2
 – Engaging Discussion & Live Q&A (40 min)
Dive deeper into CQ with expert insights, practical examples, and an open discussion to address your biggest challenges in intercultural training.
Key Discussion Points:
✅ Start with the end in mind – What does true intercultural competence look like, and how do people actually develop it?
✅ Seeing clearly through the clutter – How to assess and choose the best intercultural frameworks for your training.
✅ Your training roadmap – A step-by-step guide to using Cultural Intelligence (CQ) to design effective, results-driven intercultural training programs.
Join us for this dynamic session and gain actionable strategies to enhance your intercultural training impact! ✨
Let’s connect, learn, and lead together!
Best regards,
Young Sietar

subject: Young SIETAR Email update - IMPORTANT
body:
Young SIETAR Email update
 
 
 
Important contact notice
 
 
 
 
 
Dear Vincent,
It appears our email has been hacked and is being used for malicious or frivolous purposes. Until we are able to clear up this mess, please disregard any email you may receive from 
board@youngsietar.org
. We are actively working to correct this issue as soon as possible. 
For the foreseeable future until this mess has been cleared up, if we contact you it will be through our individual board emails. 
We apologise for any inconvenience or confusion this may have caused you. 
Yours interculturally,
The Young SIETAR Board,
(Moutushi, Veronique, Tanya, Comi, Chelmy, Lucrezia, & Christina)
 
 
Follow us on Twitter

Find us on Facebook

3, March 2025
 
 
 
 
 
Dear Vincent,
On behalf of the Young SIETAR Board, we would thank those of you who were able to attend this year's 
Young SIETAR 
General Assembly, which was held this past Sunday
, March 2nd, 2025 at 11 am  CET
.
Whether you were able to attend or not, we would now like to invite you to review our notes  from the meeting. 
Please find enclosed the official document 
YS GA 2025 Document
 for this year's General Assembly (click on the link to view). 
It contains detailed information about the topics we covered during the GA. Most importantly we were able to elect three new board members. We will be sharing more information about them soo - stay tuned! 
If you have any questions regarding the contents of this GA, please do not hesitate to contact us. Additionally, if you feel inspired after reviewing the document and have some ideas of how you would like us to proceed, whether that be volunteering with research, education & training, or communication, writing for us, leading your own webinar, or assisting with the TOIT+2026 planning, please do get in touch!

subject: Event Announcement: YS Think Intercultural Series: Intercultural Relationships with Liliana Baeckert, 04 Mar 2025
body:
Dear Vincent Bongiovanni,
You are invited to the following 
event
:
YS Think Intercultural Series: Intercultural Relationships with Liliana Baeckert
When: 04 Mar 2025 7:00 PM, CET
Where: Online
The event is in 2 days, will you be attending?
Yes
 
Maybe
 
No
 
EVENT DETAILS:
Alternate Title: "
International Love
"
Liliana Baeckert, author of the book (in Portuguese) Amores Internacionais, will be talking about intercultural relationships and international love.
Different topics to be discussed
: 
Managing cultural differences within an international romantic relationship
Managing the difficulties in the new country, new culture
Cultural differences as cultural shocks
A glamorous loving relationship, but is this really the case? 
     → One of the couple is always the migrant, and what are the consequences of their migration? 
Who does this dynamic affect more,  women or men? 
Is there even a solution for this situation? 
Liliana Tinoco Bäckert is a journalist and holds a master's degree in Intercultural Communication from the University of Lugano, Switzerland. She is a member of the Network for the Study of Journalism of Migration and Refuge in Latin American Contexts (Remolinos), at the University of São Paulo. 
In Switzerland, where she has lived since 2005, she specialized in migration and in anti-racist practices. She currently works in an office for foreign integration.
In 2020, Liliana launched the journalistic book about the reality of Brazilian women who married people from other nationalities.
Best regards,
Young Sietar

subject: Event Announcement: How to use Culture as a Catalyst for Successful Change, 26 Feb 2025
body:
Dear Vincent Bongiovanni,
You are invited to the following 
event
:
How to use Culture as a Catalyst for Successful Change
When: 26 Feb 2025 6:30 PM, CET
Where: Online
The event is in 2 days, will you be attending?
Yes
 
Maybe
 
No
 
EVENT DETAILS:
Change is inevitable, but achieving success in change initiatives is not guaranteed. You may be familiar with the quote from Heraclitus: "The only constant in life is change." In both professional and personal contexts, the key to a smooth and effective transformation lies in understanding and managing culture. Both organizations and individuals need to be culturally intelligent to navigate change successfully in today’s interconnected and rapidly evolving world. 
Intercultural management is a crucial, yet often overlooked, factor in driving successful change. This webinar, designed for Young SIETAR members—independent educators, trainers, coaches, and consultants—will explore how you can leverage cultural awareness and adaptability to create impactful and sustainable change.
In our globalized world, stakeholder management has become increasingly complex, with diverse stakeholder expectations and the growing influence of technology. Organizations must navigate the intricate dynamics of cultural differences while balancing the needs of employees, clients, and other stakeholders. The role of technology in communication and collaboration further highlights the importance of culturally intelligent leadership in change management. By understanding how cultural values influence perceptions of change and acceptance, attendees will gain valuable insights into fostering more inclusive, resilient, and effective change processes. 
Key Focus Areas:
●
      
Culture as a Change Enabler:
 How cultural values shape perceptions, behaviours, and resistance to change.
●
      
Practical Strategies: 
Tools and techniques to align change initiatives with cultural dynamics for smoother adoption and engagement.
●
      
Overcoming Resistance
: Addressing cultural barriers that hinder individual, team, and organizational transformation.
●
      
Real-World Applications:
 Interactive discussions on integrating culture into change management frameworks.
●
      
Personal and Professional Impact
: How can intercultural management skills enhance leadership, collaboration, and long-term adaptability?
●
      
Stakeholder Considerations
: Navigating diverse stakeholder expectations and leveraging technology to enhance cultural alignment in change initiatives.
Join this engaging and interactive session to discover how intercultural management can be the missing piece in your change leadership toolkit!
Mithun Mridha is a PPM Expert, Organizational Transformation Consultant and Agile Coach within Capgemini's Business Transformation Expertise Centre in Paris. He also happens to be an Intercultural Enthusiast and an International Speaker. He helps senior executives foster strategic alignment, improve project performance, and develop future leaders. He has successfully served multinationals from diverse sectors and travelled extensively in 60 countries. He has lived and worked for long periods of time in four countries. Mithun has taught International Business, Intercultural Management and Project Management at the following prestigious European Business Schools - ENPC - ParisTech, Paris Dauphine, ESSCA, EM Normandie and Freie Universität Berlin.
Best regards,
Young Sietar

subject: Event Announcement: Young SIETAR General Assembly 2025, 02 Mar 2025
body:
Dear Vincent Bongiovanni,
You are invited to the following 
event
:
Young SIETAR General Assembly 2025
When: 02 Mar 2025 11:00 AM, CET
Where: Online
It's that time of the year for (digital) General Assemblies and we as Young SIETAR have been doing digital GAs for many years.
 
GAs are an important part of any organisation and this year we as a board would encourage you to join us at our General Assembly of Young SIETAR that is taking place on 
Sunday, March 2nd,2025 at 11a
m CET.
As our valued members are located across the globe, this is an important time for the Board to speak directly to them (and vice versa) about our previous year's actions as well as our future plans for the year ahead. The Board would encourage you, member, to join us so your voice will be heard. 
As some important decisions concerning the future of Young SIETAR will be taken, we will also offer our active membership to vote beforehand by filling out an online (
Voting by proxy for Young SIETAR General Assembly2023.docx
) document. 
Our GA will be held on 
Sunday, March 2nd,2025 at 11a
m CET
.
In order to join us online, please register here:
https://attendee.gotowebinar.com/register/14280901543791448
After you’ve registered you will receive an e-mail if your registration was successful. Please make sure to join a few minutes before the start of the GA as you may have to download the software to be able to access the webinar.
The proposed agenda for the General Assembly is as follows: 
Part 1:
 
Welcome & introductions
Finalization of ther GA 2025 agenda. 
Minutes from previous GA (YS GA, 2024) 
Part 2:
 
Announcements from the board
Secretarial & Finacial overview - presentation and voting 
Changes within the Board - proposals, applications, and voting 
Part 3
: 
Annual strategy 2025 - presentation and voting
Budget 2025
Membership fee update for the year, 2025 - proposal and voting 
Question and Answer session
We expect the call to last no longer than 1.5 hours.
After the discharging of the former board members, voting will be required to approve the proposed new board members. Upon approval the new board members will be officially installed for a period of two years. The reasons for officially discharging and installing board members are legal issues, responsibilities and liability.
All members are cordially invited to apply and 'step up to the plate' for any open position advertised.
We’re looking forward to having the General Assembly together with you on 
Sunday, March 2nd,2025 at 11a
m CET,
 and are looking forward to holding our annual assembly virtually once again. 
Will you be attending?
https://attendee.gotowebinar.com/register/14280901543791448
EVENT DETAILS:
It is that time again for our (digital) General Assembly (GA). 
The General Assembly, consisting of all members of YS, is the most powerful body of our association. To ensure the daily activities of YS, the General Assembly entrusts certain tasks and responsibilities to a small group of people, the executive committee, which we call the Board. The members of the board are chosen by the General Assembly by means of voting.
The General Assembly is also meant for discussing other important ongoing issues of importance to YS and its members.
 
At least once a year a General Assembly meeting is called together by the board in which it renders an account and informs the members of the administrative and financial situation of the association. It does so in the form of a secretarial and financial report of the past year and a policy and financial preview of the coming year. The members can either approve or disapprove of the presented results and future plans.
As our valuable members are located across the globe, this is an important time to speak directly to you about our previous year's actions as well as our future plans. 
All members of YS are invited for this meeting and have a right to vote.
This event is an important part of any organization and this year we as a board encourage you to join us so your voice will be heard.
Please register for this event 
here
.
Best regards,
Young Sietar

Embracing (more) change and collaboration in 2025!
Adapting to evolving global challenges together.
Like fashion, January is out. 
February is in. 
The month that blinked and was gone. 
It is already February and we on the Board have so much to update you on. 
Read on to find out more…
 
“Ting”: The Global Coaching Secret
In Chinese culture, the concept of 
Ting
 (聽) encompasses listening with more than just the ears—it involves the eyes, heart, and mind, symbolising focused and holistic attention. 
Effective global coaching, particularly when bridging diverse contexts like the Global North and South, mirrors this approach. Coaches who 
Ting
 are fully present, observing body language, understanding emotional undercurrents, and engaging deeply with coachees. 
Moreover, treating coachees as valued partners—akin to royalty—creates a space of respect and empowerment. 
This mindful and intentional approach fosters authentic connections and drives transformational growth.
We have Jeremy Solomons to thank for his insight on 
Ting 
(聽)
, from his recent webinar on Global Coaching (See below). 
 
Global Coaching webinar with Jeremy Solomons
Helping us close out the month of January was mentor and dear friend of Young SIETAR, Jeremy Solomons. In his webinar on global coaching, he helped participants better understand the complexities and nuances of coaching in the Global North and the Global South. 
Three Important Takeaways:
Cultural Adaptation Is Essential:
 Coaching approaches that work in the Global North may not translate directly to the Global South. Coaches must be adaptable, listening carefully to the cultural and contextual needs of their coachees to foster effective and respectful communication.
Equity and Empathy Build Stronger Connections:
 Understanding the unique challenges faced by individuals in different economic and social contexts requires empathy. Successful coaches create equitable spaces where diverse perspectives are acknowledged and valued.
The Importance of Personal Connection:
 Building trust and rapport is particularly crucial when coaching in the Global South. Personal connections often form the foundation of successful coaching relationships. Taking time to get to know coachees on a human level, beyond professional objectives, can significantly enhance communication and engagement.
Members can access the recording of this webinar and Jeremy’s PDF slides in the members-only section of our website, under Training and Education.
Young SIETAR . org
 
Upcoming Events
We are working on a few great events free for members. Mark your calendars and please consider joining us. 
First, in February…
26.02.25: An evening with the ever enigmatic Mithun Mridha. Mridha is man who wears many hats and is planning to share his vast wisdom and experience as an Organisational Transformation Consultant, Coach, and Intercultural Enthusiast. Stay tuned as more information is on the horizon. 
Next we will have two events in March, so buckle up! 
02.03.25: It is that time of year again - time for our General Assembly. This is our members chance to see exactly what the YS Board has been up to in 2024 and what our plans are for 2025. Not to mention we hope to introduce new potential board members. Plus,  all members get to vote! Join us, won’t you?! 
04.03.25: We are pleased to announce the first webinar in a new series for 2025, ‘Think Intercultural’ with a plethora of wonderful speakers. 
CONFIRMED  GUEST SPEAKERS
Liliana Baeckert, Brazilian living in Switzerland, author of the book (in Portuguese) Amores Internacionais, who will be talking about intercultural relationships.
Liliana Tinoco Bäckert | LinkedIn
Dr. Catherine Wu, French living in Singapore, Professor of Cultural Intelligence and Global Leadership at Nanyang Technological University Singapore, who will be talking about designing an intercultural training having CQ in mind.
Dr. Catherine (Peyrols) Wu | LinkedIn
Sean Dubberke, Principal and VP of Learning at RW3 Culture Wizard, a firm specialized in DEI and intercultural training.
Sean Dubberke | LinkedIn
Jane Jihye Kim, South Korean based in South Korea, Intercultural Consultant, who will be talking about gender equality in South Korea. 
Jane Jihye (김지혜) Kim | LinkedIn
Members, don’t forget to check your inboxes as more information on all of these events is coming soon. 
View
 
We want to hear from you!
Do you have an idea for a webinar, a research project? 
Or perhaps an intercultural book or film recommendation that you would love to share? 
How about a training activity or research methodology that you would love our members to hear about? 
Contact us at 
board@youngsietar.org
.

body:
Young SIETAR Membership Drive 2025
 
 
 
Young Sietar Membership Update
January 23, 2025
 
 
 
 
 
We Miss You at Young SIETAR – Reconnect with Us!
Dear Vincent,
We hope this email finds you well! As a valued former member of Young SIETAR, we want to take a moment to say how much we’ve appreciated your past involvement in our diverse and dynamic community.
Young SIETAR thrives on the interests, ideas, and enthusiasm of people like you. Together, we’ve built a space where cultural exchange, professional development, and meaningful dialogue flourish. And while memberships occasionally lapse, we’d love to invite you back!
Reactivating your membership is simple and comes with big rewards:
Shape the Future
: Your voice matters in deciding the research, trainings, and webinars we prioritize.
Stay Connected
: Rejoin a global network of like-minded, whiley and young-at-heart professionals passionate about interculturalism.
Exclusive Benefits
: Enjoy access to members-only events, resources, and networking opportunities.
For just a small membership fee, you’ll regain access to everything Young SIETAR offers and have a say in its continued success. You can simply log into your existing account on our 
website
 or follow the link below. 
[
Renew Your Membership Here
]
Your perspectives and involvement are what make Young SIETAR special. We have big plans for 2025. Let’s continue learning, growing, and making an impact together!
If you have any questions or suggestions, don’t hesitate to reply to this email. We’d love to hear from you.
The Young SIETAR Board, 
( Veronique, Lucrezia, Comi, Chelmy, & Christina)

subject: Do you want to be on Board?
body:
Open Call for board positions
 
 
 
Are you on board?
January, 2025
 
 
 
 
 
Dear Vincent,
The Young SIETAR board is not yet fully complete and we are waiting on YOU to join!
 
There are four open board positions: President, Secretary, Treasurer, and Mentorship / Membership Coordinator.
We'd like to encourage you to consider running for one of the positions. All positions are volunteer, require those who hold the positions to be an active member of Young SIETAR or are willing to join, and finally require a certain level of mentoring and management in the beginning. 
Please announce your candidacy to the board by February 1st, 2025 (earlier would be highly appreciated). We would like you to be able to present yourself to the membership during the general assembly in March, 2025.
 
 
Learn more about the specific positions here: 
President Job description
Secretary Job description
Treasurer job description
Membership / mentoring job description
 
Send your questions, CV, and motivation letter to 
board@youngsietar.org
.
 
We look forward to hearing from you and to you joining our team. 
Interculturally yours,
The Young SIETAR Board
 (Veronique, Chelmy, Comi, Lucrezia, and Christina)

subject: YS Winter Newsletter
body:
Closing out 2024 - Embracing Authenticity and New Possibilities for 2025!"
 
View this email in your browser
Winter Newsletter
Let’s welcome sweater weather together!
 
Showing gratitude
Since we in the global North are now knee-deep in December. For many, this is a time of reflection and gratitude. We are no different here at Young SIETAR. 
For that reason we would like to thank our 
Board of Inspiration
 for their continued support of our rag-tag group of young-at-heart interculturalists. We look forward to your continued expertise, guidance, and future collaborations. 
 
Research Reflections on 2024
As 2024 comes to an end, the intercultural field celebrates a year of profound growth and collaboration. In a world shaped by VUCA (volatility, uncertainty, complexity, and ambiguity) and the acclerating impact of AI, Young SIETAR members and professionals worldwide have embraced the challenge of deepening intercultural understanding. 
This year brought forward communication frameworks, including the 
TRIPS Toolkit 
by Dr. Helen Spencer-Oatey, the revitalized 
TOPOI model 
by Dr. Edwin Hoffman, and 
AI-Enhanced Transcultural Communication models
. These tools remind us of the wisdom at the heart of intercultural work: that empathy, dialogue, and shared humanity remain our most powerful guides. 
As we reflect on 2024, may we find inspiration in the small yet profound steps that bring cultures closer, envisioning a future defined by connection, curiosity, and mutual respect.
Like this?  Read our Research Coordinator`s full reflection on the year on our website.
Website
*Clicking on the link will take you to our website & require you to log in as a member. 
 
Past events
Personality. Self-expression. Individuality. Creativity.
These were the key themes of the webinar we hosted with Jin Luo, an expert in personal branding and coaching. During the session, titled 
Personal Branding for Interculturalists
, Jin shared her journey of self-awareness and how embracing her multifaceted identity became the foundation of her success.
Being honest and true to ourselves is the cornerstone of personal branding. Each of us is an individual with multiple dimensions, and we should not limit these to fit into a specific context. Instead, breaking the rules and pushing boundaries allows us to unleash our potential and showcase our unique value.
Her story was an inspiration for aspiring entrepreneurs. 
The key takeaway? 
Unleash your creativity and be unapologetically yourself!
 
Upcoming events
Our board is busy planning events into 2025. 
As a little teaser, we hope to begin a new series of trainings/ webinars 
Think Intercultural
 
to help both those new to the intercultural field and seasoned professionals.
However, we hope to also be offering an insightful webinar toward the quiet end of January on 
Global Coaching
. 
Our next 
General Assembly
 (GA) will take place on 2nd, March 2025. During this digital event we will review our accomplishments, projects, research  and financial outlook from 2024, and our goals for 2025. It is a members-only event.
Finally, we are beginning to put together a team to plan our next 
Train-the-Intercultural-Trainer
 
(TOIT)
 program to take place in late 2025 or early 2026. 
More information coming soon. 
 
Looking for new board members
This past spring we welcomed three new volunteer board members to our team. However, many of you know that our board is still incomplete. We are now looking for a new 
president, secretary, treasurer, and membership coordinator
.
These are some big positions to fill so if you or someone you may know might be interested in any of these positions, we do request a 
CV and inspiration letter
. 
Additionally, we also request a period of transition which will include mentoring and management to ensure these positions are a great fit for everyone (the new candidates and the existing board). 
We will send out a separate email and post across social media about these positions soon.
Deadline for applications is 1st February, 2025
.
Positions will be voted in during our next 
General Assembly in March, 2024. 
To the blog post
*Clicking on the link will take you to our website & require you to log in as a member. 
 
Want more?
If you are already a member go over to our website to read about our upcoming events, view past webinars, learn about key research in the intercultural field, and so much more. 
We are updating our members only space all the time. 
If you are not yet a member, please consider becoming one. 
Join Us
 
And finally, before we leave you today our team would like to wish you a happy holiday season, however you celebrate (or not) this time of year. 
youngsietar.org

subject: Fall Young SIETAR Update
body:
Summer time, summer time, summer time sadness - or - are you ready in your Autumn sweater?
 
View this email in your browser
Greetings Young SIETARians, 
We on the board hope all of you wonderful members have had a great summer, if you are in the northern hemisphere, or winter, if you live in the Southern hemisphere. We all took the month of August off, but are back now to share some great news!
Read on to find out more…
But first, a question to you as we transition to a new season: are you the type to mourn this season’s end or revel in the idea of change - hence the two song lyrics in our newsletter ‘description’. Do you know which songs they are from? If so, jump onto the 
YS member’s-only forum
 (*must log in) and answer these questions and help us create our own seasonal playlist. 
YS General Assembly, 2024
The General Assembly is THE OPPORTUNITY for YS members to not only inform themselves of the ongoing business within YS but more importantly to influence the strategy set out by the board, bring in ideas for improvement, discuss issues of importance, etc. 
On the 26th of June we had our General Assembly (GA). During this all board and member meeting we were able to discuss a number of topics, including: 
our previous years goals and achievements 
our future goals
budget
electing new board members
The General Assembly (GA) is the yearly meeting of the Young SIETAR members, where key issues for the organization are presented, discussed and decided on. It is also a legal requirement to have such a meeting with all members annually.
At least once a year a General Assembly meeting is called together by the board in which it renders an account and informs the members of the administrative and financial situation of the association. It does so in the form of a secretarial and financial report of the past year and a policy and financial preview of the coming year. The members can either approve or disapprove of the presented results and future plans.
The General Assembly is also meant for discussing other important ongoing issues of importance to YS and its members. There can be more than one General Assembly per year. At the moment however, we hold only one per year. We usually hold the General Assembly during our annual congress. Since we do not have an annual congress this year, we will hold the General Assembly online. 
Perhaps most important for you, dear members, is our strategy for the coming year. 
This includes: 
Continue/restart with online events: 
Book Club, 
online webinars, 
possible trainings / discussions.
Call for proposals for new events/projects from members.
Teambuilding with the new board  
With new brainstorm about activities for TOT-Plus
New website that is secure
Finding sponsors for Wild Apricot in the future (or alternatively a new website host)
Working on visibility of YS
Social media strategy: Linkedin Posts, Facebook 
Do you have any ideas about how we should proceed with any of these points or would you like to share your expertise (or gain experience and knowledge) working on one of these points? Let us know! 
board@youngsietar.org
New Board Members
We are truly an international bunch of interculturally curious folks. 
This past June you voted to have three new board members join our team. 
Chelmy Misaki - Training Coordinator
Comi Nguyen - Research Coordinator 
Lucrezia D’Amato - Education Coordinator
Click here to meet the team
Link will open in a new window and require logging into the YS member site.
Upcoming training / webinar
We are currently working on three new webinars for our members. 
These should take place over the next few months. 
More information coming soon. 
If you would like to share your knowledge with our members, contact us. 
If you would like to practice sharing your knowledge with our members, contact us. 
If you know someone outside our membership circle who has knowledge that could benefit our members, contact us! 
board@youngsietar.org
Latest on the blog…
UBUNTU, I AM BECAUSE WE ARE
In the heart of Africa, I found a profound lesson in interconnectedness through the spirit of Ubuntu. My 2019 trip to Rwanda unveiled a nation reborn through resilience and community spirit. I explored how Ubuntu, a philosophy of shared humanity and support, continues to shape lives across Africa. From Rwanda’s amazing revival to the rich traditions of other cultures, Ubuntu weaves together nature and human connections in powerful ways. Read the full article to see how these experiences illuminate the powerful bonds that unite us all.
YS Blog
Link will open in a new window and require logging into the YS member site.
A book club suggestion
Pachinko, by MinJin Lee
Published February 2017 by Head of Zeus. 
Cover art by Tom Hallman
This is a call for the YS bookclub, to read the book and share our thoughts by our founder and current Treasurer, Veronique Killian: 
With the backdrop of the Japanese occupation of Korea, Pachinko follows the lives of a family living in Korea that re-establishes itself in Japan. The narrative progresses through the years and the events of WWII. Even as the story near modern day, its characters are never quite free of their history and the events of the past. As a reader I was invited to love the characters, invited into their thoughts, behavior as if one was looking deeply inside. 
Pachinko was a 2017 finalist for the National Book Award for Fiction.
In this book one gets a taste of the historic background and intercultural context of the time, and how the book originated to shed light on these intercultural groups. 
Meanwhile, the story has been adapted into a miniseries produced by Apple TV and a documentary about Min Jin Lee was made using both English and Korean languages. 
Who wants to be caught by this book and share together what it brought up? 
board@youngsietar.org
Other news…
Is there something missing here, or you would like to see on the website, in a future webinar, or something else you are curious about researching, learning, or doing? Contact us and perhaps we can inspire or teach each other. 
board@youngsietar.org
Copyright (C) 2024 Young SIETAR. All rights reserved.
You are receiving this email because you opted in via our website. 
Our mailing address is:
Young SIETAR Karel De Vijfdestraat 5 'S-Hertogenbosch, Brabant 5216 AP Netherlands

You can

 or

body:
Good morning team! Looking forward to seeing you today. We have our weekly all staff at 11 am central today, would it be possible to push back our meeting an hour so that we can accommodate both meetings? So – meet at 1:00 Eastern, noon central?

Subject:
 Today's LCW/GroupM Meeting and Updates
 
Hello LCW Team,
 
I may not be able to attend today’s meeting.
 
That said, we have some great news to share that I was planning on covering today.  We were able to get a platform for the registration, we’ll be using Eventbrite.  We would however like to push back the start date of our sessions to the second week of October so we can have ample time to set up the sessions (inclusive with the zoom links from LCW) and communicate the launch to our employees. 
 
Not sure if Brian could make the meeting today to answer any questions you may have or we can reschedule for Friday if necessary (the earlier the better).
 
Thank you,
 
Lukeisha Paul M. Div.
(She/Her/Hers)

Subject:
 Today's LCW/GroupM Meeting and Updates
 
Hello LCW Team,
 
I may not be able to attend today’s meeting.
 
That said, we have some great news to share that I was planning on covering today.  We were able to get a platform for the registration, we’ll be using Eventbrite.  We would however like to push back the start date of our sessions to the second week of October so we can have ample time to set up the sessions (inclusive with the zoom links from LCW) and communicate the launch to our employees. 
 
Not sure if Brian could make the meeting today to answer any questions you may have or we can reschedule for Friday if necessary (the earlier the better).
 
Thank you,
 
Lukeisha Paul M. Div.

subject: Scoro Update: Usability Improvements
body:
Good news! Your Scoro site lcw.scoro.com has been updated! We're bringing you a few small but useful usability improvements in t...
 
 
 
Log in → 
 
Good news! Your Scoro site 
lcw.scoro.com
 has been updated!
We're bringing you a few small but useful usability improvements in the project view this month, from task sorting to updated calculation logic in the budget charts. Consider it a little summer maintenance as we prepare for some bigger updates coming your way. 
See what we’ve been up to!
Task sorting in the project view
Now you can 
sort the tasks in the project view
 based on your preferred criteria to find the relevant tasks faster. Simply 
click on the respective column name
. If the project has phases, the tasks are sorted accordingly within each phase. Scoro will remember your sorting preference and apply it across all projects. 
Read more
 
Budget chart improvements
We've improved the accuracy of the budget tracking in the budget charts under 
Budget > Budget health
 in the project detailed view. 
Planned tasks are now reflected in the forecast even if they don't have set due dates
. In such cases, the project end date is used instead to distribute the task value across the future timeline. This helps to keep the forecast accurate from early on. You can understand the budget burn based on planned work even if all tasks don't have a proper due date yet. 
Read more
 
The Handbook Podcast & Newsletter
Did you know we also have a podcast? Join 
Harv Nagra
, an Ops Consultant and Ex-Agency Leader, on our podcast 
The Handbook
, , as he dives into engaging conversations with operations experts to discuss the behind-the-scenes of agency operations and explore the latest trends and innovations. You'll get practical advice on things like 
which areas to optimize to drive growth
, 
how to get better at finance
, and so much more! Subscribe to the podcast on 
Spotify
, 
YouTube
, and 
Apple
 for new bi-weekly episodes. 
And that's not all - you can also subscribe to 
our newsletter
 to get the latest info on agency challenges and solutions delivered directly to your inbox. 
Read more
 
And that's not all! 
See our blog post for more details!
We do our very best to make Scoro better every day, so we really appreciate your feedback. Let us know what you think at 
help@scoro.com
.
Yours truly,
Team Scoro
 
 
 
© 2024 Scoro Software. | 
www.scoro.com
 
Scoro Software Ltd | The Frames, 1 Phipp Street, EC2A 4PS | London, United Kingdom 
If you need assistance or have any questions, please contact our 
Customer Support
.

From:
 Sarah Nodarse <s.nodarse@lcwmail.com> 
Sent:
 Monday, August 12, 2024 2:30 PM
To:
 Lukeisha Paul <Lukeisha.Paul@groupm.com>; Juri Mansour <j.mansour@lcwmail.com>
Cc:
 Safa Aamir <safa.aamir@groupm.com>; Shelton Rankin <shelton.rankin@groupm.com>; Brian Dashew <brian.dashew@groupm.com>
Subject:
 RE: LCW - FW: Action Required: Managing Bias in the Workplace Registration
 
External:
 
 
Hi Lukeisha,
 
Now that you have approved the dates, we can go ahead and work on the zoom links. Give us a few days to get the links created. Juri can work with our internal team and provide a timing update on that.
 
Regarding the survey, we typically do this upon request with clients. As you remember, we did it for the last program. There are some things to consider:
-What are you trying to measure – comprehension of concepts learned? Change in attitude? Change in behavior? The questions would have to be tailored accordingly
 
**I recall when we discussed measurements for a survey last time we said change would not make sense as we don’t anticipate change just from a one-time session.  We decided comprehension of concepts, a before and after to gage if anything was learned.  I was looking for your thoughts on which concepts / learned behavior you believe attendees can grasp from the workshop without putting into practice yet but that would help modify behavior once applied.
 
-How will you use the data? This will need to be specified in the survey instructions so that people know when they are responding how their answers will be used
 
**The data would be used to access the understanding of the content of the workshop and perhaps where we need to emphasize with a future learning opportunity.  
 
-What platform will you use? When we did this last time, we used LCW’s survey monkey account
 
**We can use Microsoft Forms.   
 
-How will the link be sent out? Will we use the communications we are already working on or will there be additional communications needed?
 
**The link for the survey will be sent out via email for registration. 
 
In our last engagement, the survey was included as an additional (paid) deliverable. As an alternative, since I know you don’t have any additional budget, what we could do is advise you on the questions to ask but have GroupM run the survey internally. I’m happy to be a thought partner in designing questions for you to use.
 
**This would be helpful based on your expertise a well as experience across some of your other clients.
 
Regarding the communications, thank you for sending over the example, it aligns with what I remember. We have the created the attached, which has all the information about the courses (description, learning objectives). Of course, for the invitation piece, we have details to fill in (the zoom links, notably!). Let us know if you need any other support on this!
 
Thank you,

Subject:
 Action Required: Managing Bias in the Workplace Registration
 
 
Register for Managing Bias in the Workplace Workshop
LUKEISHA PAUL
November 10, 2022
 
Hello Everyone,
You all should’ve received an email from Serena Anthony, CPO NA about GroupM’s commitment to Managing Bias in the Workplace.  (Attached for your reference).
Overview:  
We all have unconscious biases; being aware of how they show up and getting tools to address them can help to foster a more inclusive, empathetic environment through our interactions and communications with each other. Each week during the duration of the Managing Bias Workshop, a select group of employees will receive an invitation to participate until all of our 6,000+ employees have participated.  
This is your group email!
Long story short: 
 This is your invitation to register for an upcoming Managing Bias in the Workplace workshop.
 
Please click here to the Managing Bias in the Workplace site to reserve your seat.
  
We recommend signing up for the earliest session you can accommodate in your calendar.
 
Getting Credit:  
As a reminder, all employees are required to do this workshop.   In order to be marked as having completed the course, we require that you arrive on time to the session. You must be present for the full session unless an exception for shortened attendance is requested and granted by Lukeisha Paul. Attendance will be taken with
 
your company email
 and the Zoom attendance logs.
 
Important to Note:  
Do not register for multiple sessions; doing so will take up spots from other team members.
Do not forward this email to anyone else; each employee has been assigned to a group so that we can accommodate everyone.
Register with your 
work email address
, not a personal email address.
When you sign in for the workshop, 
use your first and last name
 in order to receive credit for completing the workshop.
Workshops will begin promptly. Please show our facilitators courtesy by arriving on time.
 
To get started:
  
Click the above link to access the Managing Bias in the Workplace workshop. Links to the below steps can be found on the website.
Step 1:
 For more information about this program, click the "1. Introduction" icon below.
Step 2:
 Click the "2. Pre-Session Survey" icon below to take the 5-minute survey.  The data collected in this survey is anonymous and will help us in our efforts towards continuous improvement of our learning and DEI programming. 
Step 3:
 Click the "3. Registration Link" icon to register for your preferred session. 
Only register for one session
.  After completing your registration, you will receive an invite from Outlook to attend. 
 
If you have any questions, please reach out to 
Lukeisha Paul
 or Shelton Rankin
 
 
Lukeisha Paul M. Div.
(She/Her/Hers)
Head of Diversity, Equity & Inclusion, GroupM US

tong@chinapropartners.com
>
Sent:
 Wednesday, July 24, 2024 9:54 PM
To:
 Vince Bongiovanni <
v.bongiovanni@lcwmail.com
>
Subject:
 Re: LCW Facilitation Opportunity
 
 
Hi, Vince, 
 
Thanks for your message! I am interested and I’m a mandarin speaking trainer. Will the materials be translated and delivered in Mandarin? 
 
A couple of questions: 
Finished reading the deck, I’m not very clear what we would like to achieve by this training. Understand it’s a training for working inclusively and it’s still being developed. 
A few things that I’d like to see included in the discussion: 
Benefit of DEI programs. Yes, it’s important to implement DEI programs. But they are not show and tells, there are real benefits from a diverse work force. I am a business owner, I would not hire just because I need to fulfill the DEI quota. It is because the different viewpoints and diverse background and experience the new hires will bring in. 
Distinction of Stereotype vs individuals. Media portrayal vs. reality. Why we should not assume when working with people from diverse background.  
The enslaved African in ancient Chinese history is an interesting trivia. But it has nothing to do with how Chinese treat or view Africans or African Americans today. It could easily be dismissed as a discussion topic since Chinese would say that that happened centuries ago, it is irrelevant today since we don’t have slavery any more. It goes back to my point b on where the stereotype comes from. How have that affected our perception. 
 
Just my two cents. Thanks! 
 
Best regards, 
 
Z.J. Tong
President
ChinaPro Marketing Partners, Inc. 
 
1245 S Michigan Ave., #219
, 
Chicago, IL 60605-2408
Work: 312-842-1988 
 
Cell: 773-680-8482
Email: 
tong@chinapropartners.com

v.bongiovanni@lcwmail.com
>

Wednesday, July 24, 2024 at 1:18 PM
To: 
"
tong@chinapropartners.com
" <
tong@chinapropartners.com
>
Subject: 
LCW Facilitation Opportunity
 
Hi ZJ,
 
I hope you are doing well.
 
We are looking for a Mandarin speaker to facilitate 2 - 3 sessions virtually in the Fall for an APAC audience for one of our clients, and wanted to reach out to see if you fit these needs and are interested/available.
 
I have attached a pdf of the deck we will be using. It is currently still being worked on, but it should give you an idea of how the training will go.
 
If you speak Mandarin and are interested, please let me know when you can. If not, perhaps you would know someone who is that you can recommend.
 
Thanks so much for your consideration, and I look forward to hearing back .
 
Best,
Vince 
 
Vince Bongiovanni

LCW

I live and work in Chicago, IL – on the unceded territory of the Pokagon band of Potawatomi. See 
this article
 in the Chicago History Museum Magazine for a native perspective on land acknowledgements and the City of Chicago.

subject: RE: Growing a One GroupM Culture Deck - LCW Updates
body:
Thanks Shelton, I got it now.
 
I’ve added those slides to the deck, here is an updated PDF for everyone’s reference. I also changed the title to “Building an Inclusive GroupM Culture.”
 
Juri will be in touch with an updated schedule for your approval!
 
Thank you and talk soon,
Sarah

Kind regards,
Shelton
